dataset.title: Wintering marine birds and mammals in the northern Gulf of Alaska: 1997 - 2001

creator.organizationName: ABR, Inc., Environmental Research and Services
ABR, Inc., Environmental Research and Services

associatedParty.organizationName: ABR Inc., Environmental Research and Services

abstract.para:
We examined the distribution and abundance of marine birds and mammals in the northern Gulf of Alaska over five seasons during the winters of 1997-2001. We recorded 58 species of seabirds, which were dominated numerically by five species; species-richness was greatest in October and May and lowest in December and March. Abundance was greatest in May and October, in the winters of 1997-1998 and 1999-2000, and, depending on the species, at the shelf-break front or in the mid-shelf. The shelf-break front is highly important to the overwinter survival of a variety of bird and mammal species; the mid-shelf zone appears to be important to a suite of diving seabirds that concentrate on nekton, especially fishes. We recorded 10 species of marine mammals, which were dominated numerically by Dall's Porpoises; the seasonal pattern of species-richness was identical to that seen for seabirds. Abundance of Dall's Porpoises was greatest in the Alaska Coastal Current, whereas several other species were concentrated at the shelf-break or widespread. We conclude that an at-sea monitoring program can provide valuable information on wintering seabirds and recommend that a seabird monitoring component be added to the proposed Gulf Ecosystem Monitoring Program.
Publications: Day, R. H., and A. K. Prichard. 2004. Biology of wintering marine birds and mammals in the northern Gulf of Alaska. Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Restoration Project Final Report (Restoration Project 00287), ABR Inc., Environmental Research and Services, Fairbanks, Alaska.

section.title: Methods Overview
section.para: We collected data on the at-sea distribution and abundance of seabirds and marine mammals during a series of 16 oceanographic research cruises in the northern Gulf of Alaska from October 1997 through March 2001. We sampled seabirds and marine mammals on similar time and space scales as those sampled by the Gulf of Alaska GLOBEC Program. Although the emphasis was on a cross-shelf oceanographic line that ran from the mouth of Resurrection Bay (in the Alaska Coastal Current) to approximately 230 km offshore (in the Alaska Stream), we opportunistically collected data at other locations.

We collected data on the at-sea distribution and abundance of seabirds with a series of strip-transects, following standard methodology. In essence, data are collected in a zone 300 m off one side of the ship while it moves forward in a straight line at a known and fixed speed, creating a strip of ocean that has been sampled. The data then are standardized as estimates of density (birds/km²). We binned the data at a scale of approximately 2–3 km (i.e., a 10-min transect at a mean ship's speed of 10 kt) prior to analysis.

For seabirds, we examined overall patterns of species-richness seasonally, interannually, and geographically (i.e., across the shelf, from inshore to oceanic water). We examined differences in density and biomass for the most-common individual species, for all species combined, for feeding-method guilds, and for prey-type guilds by season, year, and habitat. We examined the percentage of the total avifauna for each species on each research cruise. We calculated the mean group-size and the mean sea-surface temperature and salinity in which each species occurred. We summarized and examined seasonal patterns of plumage characteristics. We also summarized and described any feeding that we saw. Finally, we plotted the distribution of the most-common species by season.

During the bird transects, we also collected data on the distribution and abundance of marine mammals, both on and off transect and both when the ship was moving and while we were stopped on oceanographic station. During sampling, we recorded all marine mammals seen anywhere in a 180 degree arc in front of the ship. We then standardized the data as estimated abundance indices (animals/h of sampling) and examined overall patterns of species-richness seasonally, interannually, and geographically. Finally, we examined differences in abundance indices for each species by cruise and summarized sea-surface temperature and salinity and habitat used by each species.

section.title: Study Area
section.para: The study area encompasses the northern Gulf of Alaska, including both neritic and oceanic areas, and nearby Prince William Sound. It includes the 220 km long Seward Line, which extends across the shelf and continental slope, and several other high-resolution lines that sample the shelf and the Alaska Coastal Current upstream, downstream, and within Prince William Sound. Although the Seward and Cape Fairfield lines were sampled on every cruise, only some of the additional lines were sampled on any cruise. However, the only line that we were able to collect seabird and marine mammal data on during every cruise was the Seward Line; we were able to sample the Cape Fairfield Line several times, but many of the other lines were sampled only once, while the ship was running between two points.
PHYSICAL OCEANOGRAPHY

In winter, the dynamics of the Gulf of Alaska are linked to the position and strength of the Aleutian Low. Storms enter the Gulf, are blocked by the coastal mountains, and cause high precipitation that forms an enormous freshwater pool that enters the shelf all along the coast (Royer 1979, 1982); these storms also generate persistently directional winds that force a cyclonic circulation and drive an onshore surface Ekman drift. The seasonal variability in freshwater discharge and wind stress is large. Seasonal runoff peaks in early fall, decreases rapidly through winter (when precipitation primarily is stored as snow), and exhibits a secondary peak in spring during low-elevation snowmelt and river breakup (Royer 1982). Cyclonic winds dominate from November to March, whereas weakly anticyclonic winds dominate in summer (Royer 1975, Wilson and Overland 1986). The cyclonic winds and discharge jointly force a mean cyclonic along-shore flow over the Gulf's shelf and continental slope (Reed and Schumacher 1986).

The Alaska Coastal Current is the most prominent circulation feature of the shelf; it is a rapidly flowing current that typically occurs within 35 km of the coast (Royer 1981a, 1981b, Johnson et al. 1988) and is generated by the above freshwater input. This current is a persistent feature flowing around the Gulf of Alaska for approximately 2,500 km from its origin over the British Columbia shelf to its entrance into the Bering Sea, in the western Gulf. Much of the Alaska Coastal Current loops through southern Prince William Sound (Niebauer et al. 1994), making it an important advective and migratory pathway for material and organisms between the shelf and the Sound. Overall inflow tends to occur at Hinchinbrook Entrance, and the primary outflow occurs at Montague Strait, with the smaller passes in this vicinity also helping to drain the Sound. Occasionally, jets of Alaska Coastal Current water are advected offshore, into mid-shelf water, at promontories. Locations where this advection are most common are at points of land: at Kayak Island (Cape St. Elias), Montague Island (the vicinity of Cape Cleare), and the Chiswell Islands on the Kenai Peninsula.

The most pronounced characteristic of the mid-shelf region is that flow there is highly different from the inshore Alaska Coastal Current and the offshore Alaska Stream, both of which exhibit strong westward flow. In contrast, mid-shelf flow is weak on average but is variable, possibly for several reasons (Niebauer et al. 1981, Lagerloef 1983, Ahlnaes et al. 1987). In addition, recent data collected during these studies suggest that jets of Alaska Coastal Current water occasionally are advected offshore, into the surface layers of this mid-shelf water (see vertical sections of hydrography and plan views of Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler [ADCP] surface velocities at the Gulf of Alaska GLOBEC website http://murphydome.ims.uaf.edu:8000/globec/results/).

Shelf hydrography and circulation vary seasonally and are driven by these annual cycles of winds and freshwater discharge. In fall, summer stratification weakens, but cross-shelf density gradients are large, and the front at the outer edge of the Alaska Coastal Current steepens to form a 30-km-wide wedge of low-salinity water adjacent to the coast. In contrast, lower freshwater input and higher onshore winds during the winter cause an overall narrowing of the Alaska Coastal Current. In spring, vertical and cross-shelf density gradients are weak as a result of winter mixing, and this front, which often lies only approximately 10 km offshore at this time, extends from the surface to the bottom. In summer, both vertical and cross-shelf density gradients are strong, and the Alaska Coastal Current is surficial only but extends to approximately 40 km offshore. These different frontal structures imply seasonally varying dynamics (e.g., Chapman and Lentz 1994) that affect the transport and dispersal of material across and along the shelf. The surface layer of the Alaska Coastal Current spreads offshore as discharge increases (Johnson et al. 1988). This cross-shelf circulation pattern might accumulate plankton or micronekton; hence, it might attract foraging fishes that then are eaten by seabirds.

The shelf-break region is an area of complex physics, and the dynamics of the shelf-break front in this region are poorly understood. From vertical sections of hydrography (at the GLOBEC website listed above), it is clear that a front may be present at the bottom, at the surface, at both, or at neither. Further, if a front is present at both the surface and the bottom, it actually may represent two different fronts that are not connected. In addition, the bottom front appears to move inshore and detach from the bottom in summer and may be the primary mechanism for nutrient replenishment onto the shelf through the advection of nutrient-rich water from offshore to
the inner shelf (T. J. Weingartner, Institute of Marine Sciences, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, AK, pers. comm.).

Upper-layer flow along the shelf-break and inner slope is westward but is considerably stronger than that over the mid-shelf (Royer 1981a). Along the continental slope, flow consists of the broad, diffuse Alaska Current in the northeastern Gulf of Alaska that becomes transformed into the narrow, rapidly flowing Alaska Stream in the northern Gulf. This current is the northernmost part of the North Pacific Subarctic Gyre and provides a connection between the oceanic North Pacific and the Gulf of Alaska's shelf. The slope circulation probably is altered during the passage of westward-moving, 200-km-diameter eddies from the eastern Gulf of Alaska (Musgrave et al. 1992, Okkonen 1992).
PRIMARY PRODUCTIVITY AND NUTRIENTS

The few primary production measurements made in the Gulf of Alaska are widely scattered. It appears that the largest production rates occur on the shelf, but the seasonal cycle is poorly described, and no data on interannual variability are available (Parsons 1986, Sambrotto and Lorenzen 1986). Because the coastal runoff is nutrient-poor, the major nutrient source to the shelf is the deep ocean (Sambrotto and Lorenzen 1986). GLOBEC results so far suggest that the near-surface (less than 50 m) nutrient concentrations on the shelf vary strongly among seasons and years, with the euphotic zone being nutrient-depleted in summer (Ruehs et al. 1999). Initial estimates for primary production during the spring bloom are approximately 2 g C per m2 per day.
ZOOPLANKTON

The zooplankton community on the shelf of the Gulf of Alaska is dominated by a combination of oceanic and neritic herbivorous and omnivorous copepod stocks (Cooney 1986a, 1986b; Incze et al. 1996). The primary oceanic species include Neocalanus plumchrus, N. cristatus, N. flemingeri, Eucalanus bungii, and Metridia pacifica; the primary neritic species include Pseudocalanus spp. and Calanus marshallae. Several micronektonic zooplankters also are important prey for fishes and birds, including the euphausiids Thysanoessa inermis, T. spinifera, and Euphausia pacifica and the amphipods Parathemisto pacifica, Cyphocaris challengeri, and Primno macropa (Ainley and Sanger 1979, Sanger 1987, Sanger and Ainley 1988, Incze et al. 1996). Oceanographic conditions affect the production and transport of these zooplankters and influence their distribution, abundance, and availability as prey for fishes and seabirds.

Between 25 and 78 percent of the shelf copepod biomass in spring and summer is dominated by oceanic species (Cooney 1986a, 1986b; Incze et al. 1996; K. O. Coyle, Institute of Marine Sciences, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, AK, unpubl. data). The geographic distribution of oceanic and neritic copepods is determined largely by cross-shelf transport and water-mass type (Cooney 1986a, Incze et al. 1996, Napp et al. 1996). In the northern Gulf, maximal copepod biomass also varies greatly among years (Incze et al. 1996, Napp et al. 1996; Coyle, unpubl. data). Further, data suggest a doubling in average biomass of zooplankton in the Gulf of Alaska as a whole between 1956-1962 and 1980-1989 (Brodeur and Ware 1992). The reasons for this increase are unclear, but hypotheses include greater primary productivity due to a rise in winter and summer wind stress and northward displacement and increased flow of the Gulf of Alaska Gyre in the 1980s (Wickett 1967, Frost 1983, Brodeur and Ware 1992, Welschmeyer et al. 1993).
FISHES

Six Pacific salmon species that spawn and are harvested in Alaska waters grow and mature in the oceanic Subarctic Pacific Ocean. Alaska salmon were abundant in the 1930s, rare in the 1960s, and abundant again in the 1980s (Rogers 1986). It appears that survivorship in the ocean affects these cycles and that current salmon abundance reflects long-term climatic changes associated with plankton productivity described above (Brodeur and Ware 1992). There also is an apparent relationship between the abundance of Alaska salmon and the positive phase of the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO; Mantua et al. 1997, Hare et al. 1999). The PDO and freshwater

discharge are strongly correlated, suggesting a possible relationship between enhanced discharge and salmon recruitment (Marshall 1992), but the exact mechanism for this relationship is not known. The doubling of overall salmon production between the 1950s and 1980s (Rogers 1986) suggests that salmon benefit from increased zooplankton biomass (Brodeur and Ware 1992).

At least 150 species of fishes occur in the Gulf of Alaska (Rogers et al. 1986). Of these, only a few are commercially important (e.g., salmonids, gadids, and flatfishes). Both squids and a few species of forage fishes (Pacific herring, Capelin, Pacific sand lance, pollock, myctophids) form a major component of the diets of a wide range of other fishes, seabirds, and marine mammals. Most of the other species, however, are unimportant commercially; consequently, little is known about their biology or trophic relationships.
BIRDS

The Gulf of Alaska supports enormous numbers of marine-oriented birds on an annual basis (Gould et al. 1982, DeGange and Sanger 1986). Over 9,000,000 seabirds nest in the Gulf; the highest at-sea densities occur on the shelf and at the shelf-break (DeGange and Sanger 1986), suggesting that these locations are important areas of energy transfer. The limited data suggest that there is seasonal variation in overall abundance, with lower numbers in winter and up to 40,000,000 seabirds feeding in the Gulf during summer (Gould et al. 1982).

Although extensive studies of seabirds have been conducted in the Gulf of Alaska for 25 years, few data are available for comparison with this study. For example, data in Gould et al. (1982) are presented by season, but few data are available for this region for most months, especially for particular locations on the Gulf of Alaska's shelf and slope. Consequently, seasonal patterns described by these authors are only general. In addition, one of only three interannual comparisons of seabird abundance in this region was conducted within a series of bays on Kodiak Island since the late 1970s (Forsell and Gould 1981; D. Zwiefelhofer, USFWS, Kodiak, AK, pers. comm.); these surveys were conducted only in winter but they were conducted only within bays, also making comparisons with this present study difficult. However, they do suggest that seabird numbers often vary dramatically among years, again a pattern that we have seen for the open shelf at all seasons. The other two studies comparing interannual abundance, including winter, are those conducted as part of research after the Exxon Valdez oil spill (Klosiewski and Laing 1994; Day et al. 1995, 1997a, 1997b; Wiens and Parker 1995, Wiens et al. 1996, 2001; Murphy et al. 1997; Agler et al. 1999, Lance et al. 1999, Irons et al. 2000). However, neither of these two groups of studies collected data on the wintering ecology of seabirds in the open northern Gulf of Alaska. Instead, they concentrated on birds in Prince William Sound, with just one study (Day et al. 1997a) focused on birds in the Gulf, and that occurring only within bays and only during the summer.
MAMMALS

At least 26 species of marine mammals inhabit the Gulf of Alaska (Calkins 1986). They are predators that consume an estimated biomass approaching 10^7 mt of food on an annual basis. Fin and Sei whales and Dall's Porpoises represent the largest components of the marine-mammal community, with each estimated to eat 1.3-2.2 × 10^6 mt of prey annually (Calkins 1986); given recent increases in the Humpback Whale population, they also may consume an important amount of biomass annually. Harbor Seals, Steller's Sea Lions, and Northern Fur Seals are the primary pinnipeds of the Gulf, with the former two species also breeding there; Elephant Seals also come from California to forage in the Gulf during much of the year. All except Elephant Seals also are exhibiting long-term declines in population size, with the sea lion now classified as endangered under the Endangered Species Act (Marine Mammal Commission 2000). Reasons for these declines are not entirely clear, however

section.title: Data Collection
section.para: We collected data on the at-sea distribution and abundance of seabirds and marine mammals during a series of 16 oceanographic cruises in the northern Gulf of Alaska from October 1997 through March 2001. Because the emphasis of the study was on wintering seabirds and mammals, we collected data from October to May, rather than during the summer. During this series of cruises, there was no cruise in December 1997, and we were unable to attend the cruise in October 1998. Hence, we were able to collect data on 3 October, 3 December, 4 March, 3 April, and 3 May cruises.

We sampled seabirds and marine mammals on time and space scales similar to those sampled by the Gulf of Alaska GLOBEC Program, using the primary oceanographic stations sampled by that study. These include the Seward Line and, when possible, the Cape Fairfield Line, Montague Strait, Knight Island Passage, and the Hinchinbrook Entrance Line. The Seward Line, which was sampled on every cruise, extended across the shelf to the Alaska Stream, including Alaska Coastal Current water, mid-shelf water, the shelf-break, and oceanic water in the Alaska Stream. The Cape Fairfield Line encompassed primarily Alaska Coastal Current water and, secondarily, mid-shelf water. Stations bracketing Hinchinbrook Entrance determined characteristics of water flowing into Prince William Sound, whereas stations in the Sound were used to determine chlorophyll concentrations and the abundance and species composition of the zooplankton and fishes exported from the Sound onto the shelf. Station spacing varied from less than or equal to 10 km on the shelf and shelf-break to approximately 18 km off the shelf. The Gulf of Alaska GLOBEC Program conducted six cruises per year to capture the seasonal cycle in important physical and biological variables, although we collected data on only the five cruises per year that encompassed the winter period.

During as many cruises as possible, we recorded data on sea-surface temperatures (SST') and sea-surface salinities (SSS's) for as many 5-min transect samples as possible. These data were taken from an automatically recorded environmental data-collection system aboard the ship, with these particular variables measured from water flowing through the sea chest. Although SST's were measured to the nearest 0.001 degree Celsius and SSS's were measured to the nearest 0.001 Practical Salinity Units (psu), we rounded both for this study to the nearest 0.1 degree Celsius and 0.1 psu. Problems with this data-collection system occasionally caused no data to be collected on some cruises.
BIRDS

We collected data on the at-sea distribution and abundance of seabirds with a series of strip-transects (long, narrow sampling zones of known area), following the methodology of Gould and Forsell (1989). In essence, data are collected in a zone 300 m off one side of the ship (i.e., from directly forward to 90 degrees starboard) while it moves forward in a straight line at a known and fixed speed. Data on flying seabirds are collected with the "snapshot method" to avoid inflation of density estimates caused by the movement of birds through the transect (Tasker et al. 1984, Gould et al. 1989), whereas data on birds on the water are collected continuously. In the "snapshot method," one quickly scans for all birds flying within the zone of interest approximately every 1 min (to approximately 300 m ahead of the ship), or about the distance covered by the ship in 1 min at 10 kt (the usual speed of the R/V Alpha Helix); a second scan usually is done to check for birds missed on the first scan and for birds in the far corner of the sampling rectangle beyond the 300-m arc of view as the ship moves. (Because the sweep of view is 300 m, a box 300 m × 300 m is incompletely sampled in the outermost corner unless the observer again searches the outer part of the transect after the ship has moved forward.) Birds on the water are sampled continuously with repeated scans because they often are difficult to locate and because they are not moving through the transect.

Although some authors (e.g., Becker et al. 1997) have argued for the use of line-transects, rather than strip-transects, in estimating at-sea densities of birds, line-transect data are so cumbersome to conduct that the resulting data are essentially worthless when more than a couple of birds are recorded on a transect. Consequently, line-transects are used for sampling more often in tropical seabird studies (where bird densities are very low) than in high-latitude ones (where densities are much higher overall).

We recorded data in two ways. First, we collected data in transects of fixed time length. Transects almost always were 5 min long, although a few were 4 min long if we were arriving at an oceanographic station. Second, within transects, we recorded data by the minute, allowing calculation of exact location and allowing clumping of data for analyses.

Ship's speed varied with seas state and direction, wind speeds and direction, currents, and differences in speed settings each time we left a station. Ship's speed averaged 10.0 plus or minus SE less than 0.1 kt (n = 4,448 5-min transect samples), or approximately 18.5 km/h, although it varied between 5.6 kt (10.3 km/h) and 12.3 kt (22.6 km/h).

At the beginning of each transect, we recorded survey line number (a number assigned for each long run of the ship in a straight line; some lines, such as the Seward Line, were sampled each cruise, whereas others were sampled only once, depending on the ship's course of travel); visit number to that part of the line (usually 1 or 2, but occasionally 3 samples on a given stretch of a survey line within a cruise); transect number within that line (numbered sequentially, from 1 to n, for each 5-min sample on that line during that cruise); coordinates (latitude, longitude); time (local, including Daylight Savings Time in winter); survey width (usually 0.300 km, but smaller if in fog or snow); length of sample (usually 5 min, but occasionally 4 min); ship's speed (to the nearest 0.1 kt, with speeds averaged every hour and changing in less time if the ship's speed was

intentionally changed); observation conditions (poor, fair, good, very good, excellent); Beaufort condition (following the Beaufort scale of wind speed and wave height); date (local); Julian date; cruise number; year; season (October, December, March, April, May); and observer (to minimize inter-observer variation, RHD collected data on all cruises except one; Randall S. Mullen
collected data on the October 2000 cruise). At the end of each 5-min transect, we recorded ending coordinates.

For each record of a bird, we recorded time; species; total number of individuals of that species; number of that species by plumage (Alternate [breeding], Basic [winter], molting [bird exhibiting molt], and unknown [poor look at bird or species exhibits no seasonal variation in plumage]); number of that species by age (adult, subadult, juvenile [i.e., less than1 yr old], and unknown [poor look at bird or species exhibits no age-related variation in plumage]); location (in the air, on the water; birds sitting on logs were counted as being on the water, as were those seen taking off or landing); activity (flying, sitting/resting, feeding, courting, comfort movements, sleeping, other]); and on/off transect (we recorded birds seen only on transect). We also recorded comments on some observations, such as ages of subadult gulls and whether or not molting jaegers had long central rectrices.
MAMMALS

During the avian sampling, we also collected data on the distribution and abundance of marine mammals. Because the emphasis was on birds, we considered the mammal data collection to be secondary in importance. We collected data on mammals primarily during periods when we were sampling for birds; we also recorded data on mammals seen while we were stopped on
oceanographic station.

During sampling, we recorded all marine mammals seen anywhere in a 180 degree arc in front of the ship (i.e., from 90 degree port to 90 degree starboard). Only those seen within 300 m of one side of the ship, in the same sampling zone as that for seabirds, were recorded as being "on transect," however. All others seen beyond the 300-m-wide sampling zone and all seen on station were recorded as being "off transect."

For each record of a mammal, we recorded time; species; total number of individuals of that species; number of that species by age (adult, subadult, juvenile [i.e., less than 1 yr old], and unknown [most marine mammals]); activity (sitting/resting, feeding, courting, comfort movements, sleeping, other [unknown and most marine mammals]); and on/off transect (we recorded all marine mammals, whether on or off transect). We also recorded comments on some observations, such as behavior and approximate locations of marine mammals if off transect.

project.title: Seabird-Oceanographic Relationships in the Northern GOA: Integration with NSF/NOAA Study GLOBEC

funding.para: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council project number 00287; ship time was provided by the National Science Foundation to the Institue of Marine Sciences, University of Alaska, Fairbanks; Robert Ritchie provided travel funds and salary for some of the data collection

dataTable.entityDescription: Bird counts, plumage, age and behavior from opporunistic ship surveys in the Gulf of Alaska, 1997 - 2001

attribute.attributeDefinition: Record number?
Line segment name for that distance between one station and the station directly below it.

Number sequentially, from 1 to n, for every sample on that line during a cruise. Hence, any transects that duplicate segments of a survey line still are numbered consecutively. Discard transects less than 4 min long.
TIME (use 24-hr clock)

Beginning latitude, degrees. Record every 5 min and at the end of a period of sampling. Note that whole degrees and minutes (to nearest 0.1 min) are listed in separate columns in the electronic data file. Hemisphere info is listed at the end of the electronic file. For consecutive transects, the ending coordinates for one transect are the beginning coordinates for the next transect. At the end of a string of transects, make sure you record the ending coordinates for the final transect at the end of that transect.

Begin latitude, minutes. Record every 5 min and at the end of a period of sampling. Note that whole degrees and minutes (to nearest 0.1 min) are listed in separate columns in the electronic data file. Hemisphere info is listed at the end of the electronic file. For consecutive transects, the ending coordinates for one transect are the beginning coordinates for the next transect. At the end of a string of transects, make sure you record the ending coordinates for the final transect at the end of that transect.

Begin longitude, degrees. Record every 5 min and at the end of a period of sampling. Note that whole degrees and minutes (to nearest 0.1 min) are listed in separate columns in the electronic data file. Hemisphere info is listed at the end of the electronic file. For consecutive transects, the ending coordinates for one transect are the beginning coordinates for the next transect. At the end of a string of transects, make sure you record the ending coordinates for the final transect at the end of that transect.

Begin longitude, minutes. Record every 5 min and at the end of a period of sampling. Note that whole degrees and minutes (to nearest 0.1 min) are listed in separate columns in the electronic data file. Hemisphere info is listed at the end of the electronic file. For consecutive transects, the ending coordinates for one transect are the beginning coordinates for the next transect. At the end of a string of transects, make sure you record the ending coordinates for the final transect at the end of that transect.

End latitude, degrees. Record every 5 min and at the end of a period of sampling. Note that whole degrees and minutes (to nearest 0.1 min) are listed in separate columns in the electronic data file. Hemisphere info is listed at the end of the electronic file. For consecutive transects, the ending coordinates for one transect are the beginning coordinates for the next transect. At the end of a string of transects, make sure you record the ending coordinates for the final transect at the end of that transect.

End latitude, minutes. Record every 5 min and at the end of a period of sampling. Note that whole degrees and minutes (to nearest 0.1 min) are listed in separate columns in the electronic data file. Hemisphere info is listed at the end of the electronic file. For consecutive transects, the ending coordinates for one transect are the beginning coordinates for the next transect. At the end of a string of transects, make sure you record the ending coordinates for the final transect at the end of that transect.

End longitude, degrees. Record every 5 min and at the end of a period of sampling. Note that whole degrees and minutes (to nearest 0.1 min) are listed in separate columns in the electronic data file. Hemisphere info is listed at the end of the electronic file. For consecutive transects, the ending coordinates for one transect are the beginning coordinates for the next transect. At the end of a string of transects, make sure you record the ending coordinates for the final transect at the end of that transect.

End longitude, minutes. Record every 5 min and at the end of a period of sampling. Note that whole degrees and minutes (to nearest 0.1 min) are listed in separate columns in the electronic data file. Hemisphere info is listed at the end of the electronic file. For consecutive transects, the ending coordinates for one transect are the beginning coordinates for the next transect. At the end of a string of transects, make sure you record the ending coordinates for the final transect at the end of that transect.
SPEED (to the nearest 0.1 kt). Record every 5 min and average over your samples.
LENGTH OF TIME SAMPLED (to the nearest 1 minute; delete sample if time less than 4 minutes)

WIDTH OF SAMPLING ZONE (to the nearest 0.050 km) (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). Default is 0.300 km; use narrower width if fog or snow prevents a broader look. Write in comments and flag if less than 0.300 km.
AREA SAMPLED (km2). Calculated automatically from speed, length, and width. [Formula in Excel is (speed*length (min)*width)*(0.030867)]
SPECIES code (see attached list for biomass, feeding type, prey type)
TOTAL NUMBER (number of birds for that line of data)
PLUMAGE (all numbers should add up to TOTAL NUMBER). Alternate = standard breeding plumage. Count of birds with alternate plumage entered in column.
PLUMAGE (all numbers should add up to TOTAL NUMBER). Basic = standard winter plumage. Count of birds with basic plumage in column.
PLUMAGE (all numbers should add up to TOTAL NUMBER). Molt = bird clearly is undergoing heavy molt, so that exact age/plumage is not certain. Count of birds molting in column.
PLUMAGE (all numbers should add up to TOTAL NUMBER). Unknown = unsure of exact plumage; always true for all tubenoses. Count of birds with this plumage in column.
AGE (all numbers should add up to TOTAL NUMBER). Count of adults; Adult = definitive plumage
AGE (all numbers should add up to TOTAL NUMBER) Count fo subadults; Subadult = that of a species having a recognizable plumage; write age-class if recognizable in comments
AGE (all numbers should add up to TOTAL NUMBER). Count of juveniles; Juvenile = <1 year old; juvenal plumage
AGE (all numbers should add up to TOTAL NUMBER). Count of unknown ages; Unknown = unsure of exact age; always true for all tubenoses except BFAL
LOCATION 0 = unknown/default 1 = in the air 2 = on the water
ACTIVITY of the bird
ON/OFF of transect. Use off-transect code for off-transect marine mammal observations or interesting observations of birds seen off transect.
OBSERVATION CONDITIONS
Beaufort scale code
Sea Surface Temperature (to the nearest 0.1°C) blank = unknown/missing
SSS (to the nearest 0.1 percent) blank = unknown/missing
Date
Julian date
Boat cruise for the line. HX followed by number
Year
SEASON (not coded on sheet—added into data file later)
AREA (not coded on sheet—added into data file later)
REGION (not coded on sheet—added into data file later)
HABITAT/REGION (not coded on sheet—added into data file later)

codeDefinition.definition: Prince William Sound/eastern Alaska Coastal Current

attribute.attributeDefinition: HABITAT STRATUM (not coded on sheet—added into data file later)
BIOMASS (to the nearest 0.001 kg) (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). Added from the sheet with the species-attribute codes.
PRIMARY FEEDING METHOD (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). Add from the sheet with the species-attribute codes.

codeDefinition.definition: surface or near-surface feeding (includes intertidal and nearshore subtidal)
deep diving (in water-column or near bottom)

attribute.attributeDefinition: PRIMARY PREY TYPE (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). Add from the sheet with the species-attribute codes.

codeDefinition.definition: other (vegetation, whatever taken by kleptoparasitism or scavenging, misc.)

attribute.attributeDefinition: SEQUENCE (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). phylogenetic sequence
DISTANCE ALONG LINE (to the nearest 0.1 km) (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). Distance calculated from innermost station on a particular line.

LINE SEGMENT (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). List that line segment for those data being associated with a line of oceanographic stations (e.g., for those stations lying between GAK1 and GAK2, write "1"; for those between GAK2 and GAK3, write "2," etc.

LSEG (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). List that line segment for those data being associated with a line of oceanographic stations (e.g., for those stations lying between GAK1 and GAK1i, write "1"; for those between GAK1i and GAK2, write "1.5," etc.
LATITUDINAL HEMISPHERE (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). All cells are N.
LONGITUDINAL HEMISPHERE (not coded on sheet—added into data file later). All cells are W.
First observer
Second observer, blank if none.

Write notes of interest on activities (e.g., feeding, courting), additional information on the environment and plumages, and any other information of interest. Flag with brackets and make notes if there is a mixed-species feeding flock; if possible, record species of prey eaten
Start latitude in decimal degrees
Start longitude decimal degrees
Station name
Station latitude in decimal degrees
Station longitude in decimal degrees

wind speed in mph
